title: 112_s508
content:
The "Chimney Rock National Monument Establishment Act" establishes the Chimney Rock National Monument in Colorado. The Act defines terms such as "national monument" and "Secretary of Agriculture." The Chimney Rock National Monument is established in Colorado to preserve various resources and provide for public interpretation and recreation. It consists of approximately 4,726 acres of land with the possibility of minor boundary adjustments to include significant archeological resources. The map showing the Chimney Rock National Monument includes significant archeological resources found after the Act's enactment on nearby National Forest System land, available for public inspection at Forest Service offices. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary is responsible for administering the national monument in line with its established purposes and relevant laws. Only uses that further these purposes are allowed. Additionally, tribal uses are governed by specific acts and policies. The Secretary administers the national monument according to its purposes and laws. Tribal members can use it for traditional ceremonies and gathering materials. Vegetation management, including timber harvesting for ecosystem restoration or fire control, is allowed. The national monument is managed by the Secretary for various purposes. Motor vehicles and mountain bikes are restricted to designated roads and trails. Grazing is allowed within the monument, subject to laws and regulations. The Secretary can renew or upgrade utility right-of-ways in accordance with the National Environmental Policy Act. The Secretary manages the national monument according to the National Environmental Policy Act and other laws. An education and interpretive center may be developed. A manager will be designated after the management plan is developed, with additional duties within the San Juan National Forest. The Secretary will develop a management plan for the national monument in consultation with relevant Indian tribes and allow public comment. The Secretary has the authority to acquire land within or adjacent to the monument through purchase, donation, or exchange. SEC. 7. WITHDRAWAL.

Federal land within the national monument is withdrawn from entry, appropriation, disposal under public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws, except for gas pipeline rights-of-way within existing easements.

SEC. 8. EFFECT. The Act does not affect water rights, tribal rights, fish and wildlife management jurisdiction, or create protective buffer zones around the national monument. The Act creates a protective perimeter around the national monument or impacts private property outside its boundary. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for carrying out the Act can be appropriated.
